issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement names the class "Course" (lines 59–76 of the problem statement), while the rest of the problem text, the template code and the solution use the class name "Lecture" (Lecture.java in template and solution). This mismatch of the class name in the UML can confuse students about which class they should implement and which attributes/constructor order the UML is referring to.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML in the problem statement to use the class name "Lecture" instead of "Course" so it matches the textual description and the code in the template and solution. Alternatively, if the intended class name is "Course", change the template and solution files and all textual references to use "Course" consistently.

issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement names the class 'Course' while the rest of the problem text and both template and solution repositories consistently use 'Lecture'. This creates a naming mismatch between the conceptual description (UML) and the actual implementation files. Students reading the UML might look for a 'Course' class in the starter code or try to name their class 'Course', causing confusion mapping requirements to the provided Lecture.java file.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across the artifacts. Change the UML diagram in problem_statement.md from 'class Course { ... }' to 'class Lecture { ... }' (or alternatively rename all occurrences of 'Lecture' in text and code to 'Course' if that was intended). Prefer aligning the UML to 'Lecture' to match the template and solution code, so students can directly map the requirements to Lecture.java.
